issues.description: The problem statement's UML defines numberOfInscribedStudents and numberOfGuestStudents as type double, but the UML methods (e.g., getTotalNumberOfStudents()) and the provided solution use int for student-related values. This creates a type mismatch that will confuse students about which type to use for the student counts and whether getTotalNumberOfStudents() should return int or double.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the types consistent. Either (A) change the two student-count attributes in the problem UML from double to int (recommended, since getTotalNumberOfStudents() and the solution use int), or (B) change the UML method return types (and the solution) to use double. Update the problem text and UML so attribute types and method return types match.

issues.description: Within the problem statement UML there is an internal inconsistency: the attributes numberOfInscribedStudents and numberOfGuestStudents are typed as double while getTotalNumberOfStudents() (in the same UML) is declared to return int. Students implementing attributes as double will be unsure whether to cast/convert when implementing getTotalNumberOfStudents().
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the internal UML contradiction by choosing a single numeric type for student counts and totals. Either make the student attributes int (and keep getTotalNumberOfStudents(): int) or make getTotalNumberOfStudents() return double to match double-typed attributes. Update the UML diagram and any textual references (e.g., 'Tip: Check the expected return type in the UML diagram') accordingly.
